segments.en: Linked Discourses 55
4. Overflowing Merit
40. Nandiya the Sakyan

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

segments.pli: Atha kho nandiyo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho nandiyo sakko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Nandiya the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

segments.pli: “yasseva nu kho, bhante, ariyasāvakassa cattāri sotāpattiyaṅgāni sabbena sabbaṃ sabbathā sabbaṃ natthi sveva nu kho, bhante, ariyasāvako pamādavihārī”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, if a noble disciple were to totally and utterly lack the four factors of stream-entry, would they live negligently?”

segments.pli: “‘Yassa kho, nandiya, cattāri sotāpattiyaṅgāni sabbena sabbaṃ sabbathā sabbaṃ natthi tamahaṃ bāhiro puthujjanapakkhe ṭhito’ti vadāmi.
segments.en: “Nandiya, someone who totally and utterly lacks these four factors of stream-entry is an outsider who belongs with the ordinary persons, I say.

segments.pli: Api ca, nandiya, yathā ariyasāvako pamādavihārī ceva hoti, appamādavihārī ca
segments.en: Neverthless, Nandiya, as to how a noble disciple lives negligently and how they live diligently,

segments.pli: taṃ suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: listen and attend closely, I will speak.

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho nandiyo sakko bhagavato paccassosi.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” Nandiya replied.
The Buddha said this:
“And how does a noble disciple live negligently?

segments.pli: Idha, nandiya, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
segments.en: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

segments.pli: itipi so bhagavā … pe … satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
So tena buddhe aveccappasādena santuṭṭho na uttari vāyamati divā pavivekāya, rattiṃ paṭisallānāya.
segments.en: They’re content with that confidence, and don’t make a further effort for solitude by day or retreat by night.

segments.pli: Tassa evaṃ pamattassa viharato pāmojjaṃ na hoti.
segments.en: When they live negligently, there’s no joy.
When there’s no joy, there’s no rapture.
When there’s no rapture, there’s no tranquility.
When there’s no tranquility, there’s suffering.
When one is suffering, the mind does not become immersed in samādhi.
When the mind is not immersed in samādhi, principles do not become clear.
Because principles have not become clear, they’re reckoned to live negligently.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nandiya, ariyasāvako dhamme … pe …
segments.en: Furthermore, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the teaching …
the Saṅgha …

segments.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi … pe … samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
segments.en: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

segments.pli: So tehi ariyakantehi sīlehi santuṭṭho na uttari vāyamati divā pavivekāya rattiṃ paṭisallānāya.
segments.en: They’re content with that ethical conduct loved by the noble ones, and don’t make a further effort for solitude by day or retreat by night.

segments.pli: Tassa evaṃ pamattassa viharato pāmojjaṃ na hoti.
segments.en: When they live negligently, there’s no joy.
When there’s no joy, there’s no rapture.
When there’s no rapture, there’s no tranquility.
When there’s no tranquility, there’s suffering.
When one is suffering, the mind does not become immersed in samādhi.
When the mind is not immersed in samādhi, principles do not become clear.
Because principles have not become clear, they’re reckoned to live negligently.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, nandiya, ariyasāvako pamādavihārī hoti.
segments.en: That’s how a noble disciple lives negligently.
And how does a noble disciple live diligently?

segments.pli: Idha, nandiya, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
segments.en: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

segments.pli: itipi so bhagavā … pe … satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
So tena buddhe aveccappasādena asantuṭṭho uttari vāyamati divā pavivekāya rattiṃ paṭisallānāya.
segments.en: But they’re not content with that confidence, and make a further effort for solitude by day and retreat by night.

segments.pli: Tassa evaṃ appamattassa viharato pāmojjaṃ jāyati.
segments.en: When they live diligently, joy springs up.
Being joyful, rapture springs up.
When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss.
And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
When the mind is immersed in samādhi, principles become clear.
Because principles have become clear, they’re reckoned to live diligently.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, nandiya, ariyasāvako dhamme … pe …
segments.en: Furthermore, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the teaching …
the Saṅgha …

segments.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi … pe … samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
segments.en: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

segments.pli: So tehi ariyakantehi sīlehi asantuṭṭho uttari vāyamati divā pavivekāya rattiṃ paṭisallānāya.
segments.en: But they’re not content with that ethical conduct loved by the noble ones, and make a further effort for solitude by day and retreat by night.

segments.pli: Tassa evaṃ appamattassa viharato pāmojjaṃ jāyati.
segments.en: When they live diligently, joy springs up.
Being joyful, rapture springs up.
When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss.
And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
When the mind is immersed in samādhi, principles become clear.
Because principles have become clear, they’re reckoned to live diligently.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, nandiya, ariyasāvako appamādavihārī hotī”ti.
segments.en: That’s how a noble disciple lives diligently.”

suttaplex.blurb: Someone who completely lacks the four factors of stream-entry is an ordinary person. But even a stream-enterer may be negligent if they do not make further effort in meditation.
